stats.pointProcess package¶

Submodules¶

stats.pointProcess.sampler module¶

class stats.pointProcess.sampler.Sampler[source]¶

Bases: object

sampleInhomogeneousPP_thinning(cifTimes, cifValues, T)[source]¶

Thining algorithm to sample from an inhomogeneous point process. Algorithm 2 from Yuanda Chen (2016). Thinning algorithms for simulating Point Prcesses.

Param

cifFun: Intensity function of the point process.

Type

cifFun: function

Param

T: the returned samples of the point process \(\in [0, T]\)

Type

T: double

Param

nGrid: number of points in the grid used to search for the maximum of cifFun.

Type

nGrid: integer

Returns

(inhomogeneous, homogeneous): samples of the inhomogeneous and homogenous point process with cif function cifFun.

Return type

tuple containing two lists

sampleInhomogeneousPP_timeRescaling(cifTimes, cifValues, T)[source]¶

Time rescaling algorithm to sample from an inhomogeneous point process. Chapter 2 from Uri Eden’s Point Process Notes.

Param

cifFun: cif function of the point process.

Type

cifFun: function

Param

T: the returned samples of the point process \(\in [0, T]\)

Type

T: double

Param

dt: spike-time resolution.

Type

dt: float

Returns

samples of the inhomogeneous point process with cif function cifFun.

Return type

list

stats.pointProcess.tests module¶

stats.pointProcess.tests.KSTestTimeRescalingAnalyticalCorrection(Y, pk, eps=1e-10)[source]¶

Y: binary sequence for the discrete time point process pk: event probability in each time been based on a conditional cif function

xks: uniform CDF rst: time rescaled times cb: 95% confidence bounds n: number of spikes

KS-test based on time-rescalling theorem ===================== Use DT Correction for Time Rescaling Theorem - Haslinger, Pipa and Brown (2010) discrete time conditional probabilities “pk” where 0<=pk<= 1

stats.pointProcess.tests.KSTestTimeRescalingAnalyticalCorrectionUnbinned(spikesTimes, cifValues, t0, tf, dt, eps=1e-10)[source]¶
